PG3 1934 üîµ

Great job! Couple of thoughts:
1) I wonder whether you have considered leveraging Marathon rather than Mesos directly? Obviously there might be non-technical reasons (e.g., marathon is not apache), but I am curious  whether technically it could make sense to take advantage of some of the nice properties that Marathon provides on top of Mesos (also comparing this to the k8s factory). 
2) Also, have you assessed the performance/scalability of the 'naive' implementation without pooling resource offers?
should have "kubernetes" label?

PG5 125 üîµ
@markusthoemmes - do you agree that there are 2 issues at play - (1) more logging failure details and (2) proper handling of `undefined` value ?

Thanks @glikson - 
1. Marathon has a different notion of lifecycle for containers than openwhisk, so I don't think that using it is a good option; although it was discussed amongst my colleagues at Adobe. Generally marathon adds a layer of container durability, so that if a container stops it will be restarted indefinitely, but this is not really something openwhisk action containers do at all - they are started, and then explicitly stopped. 
2. I think it depends on what you mean exactly by "pooling resource offers" - do you mean "holding resource offers"? FWIW, we haven't thoroughly tested the mesos-actor library in a multi-framework deployment, but our deployment is multi-framework (marathon, kafka, and openwhisk), so we need the frameworks to be good citizens that don't agressively hold resources without using them. So that is where we start. It may be good to make this tunable for different envs, where if someone does NOT have other frameworks in play, they could turn up the retention of offers, or use dynamic reservations at startup to preemptively reserve resources - but using the prewarm containers in openwhisk will already accomplish this indirectly, so it hasn't been a priority to expose it at the framework level.

Container security is handled from outside the container - access to resources and network isolation are of course necessary. There was a push to integrate AppArmor into the openwhisk code base (I‚Äôll link for posterity) but the work wasn‚Äôt completed and is delegate to on prem deployments to handle. 

We should at least revisit AppArmor integration to give a basic profile as a mode.

I can imagine how we can offer a few plugins for the artifact store. The concern as with any functionality is making sure it doesn‚Äôt rot. If there‚Äôs a way to automate the testing then we should include it. There‚Äôs on going work for Mongo as well and so we can have more than one.

this pr is not needed

> Ohhhh ofcourse. It's an array in PHP because PHP has associative arrays ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è. Good one!

To follow up on this for completeness, PHP's JSON decoder can decode to associative arrays (dictionaries) or to objects (PHP's stdClass). However, PHP's associative array handling is so strong that decoding JSON to associated arrays is more common and so that's what I made PHP Runtime do. 

As this came up, I've doubled checked by looking at a few major PHP frameworks and they all decode JSON to associative arrays. I also asked a few PHP developers that I know about what they would expect JSON decoding to look like on the PHP side and they all confirmed that associative arrays is what they would expect rather than stdClass objects.

i.e. we're doing it right for PHP, even though it's not necessarily what other languages would do.

Thanks a lot for your contribution :)
From my side, this PR looks good. I only have one question: Is there a special reason for pinning nginx to `1.13.9` isntead of `1.13`?

Oh, I wasn't offended :) It wasn't until this came up that I thought about it properly, so wanted to double check I wasn't an outlier in the PHP world on this point!
